comments.body: good catch!
nit: As discussed in the design doc, I'd prefer a float here.  So that people can specify e.g. 0.5:0.5 etc.  Unless there's a good reason why it needs to be an int?

AFAIR Brian is against any floats in the api and we don't have it anywhere. The problem with floats is that two similarly looking/computed floats may in fact be different causing various issues in comparisons.
Fair enough.  Leave as ints then.
You will need to make the same change to federation/apis/federation/v1alpha1/types.go
Will do, thx.

What version is this? Is it the git version?

How do you plan to use it?
cluster controller will use it @huangyuqi

Are we going to support this in the first phase?

How about removing Capacity and Allocatable for now, and adding them when we are ready to add support for them?

@mfanjie asked for these two fields.
cluster controller will update them @huangyuqi

In the beginning of the work, following the design spec, the replicaset would be placed to least loaded cluster, which depends on Allocatable resource of cluster. And the federation scheduler has similar logic like k8s scheduler to handle the free resource checking, prioritize cluster based on allocatable resources.
I think the random choose policy is a recent comment, and in scheduler I have both random prioritize plugin and lease loaded prioritize plugin ready.
From my view I would recommend to keep the field and the function even we do not enable them in Phase I, we will need them later anyway.
What's your call? @nikhiljindal

We should use "federated clusters" instead of "Ubernetes" in code.
How about changing this to "Information about a cluster in a federated clusters setup"?
agree

Where is the explanation for how this is intended to be used?

The name of the object is the name of the cluster?

Is the UID of the object the UID of the cluster?

Are clusters namespaced?
https://github.com/quinton-hoole/kubernetes/blob/2015-01-05-ube-design-docs/docs/design/federation-phase-1.md

Just to reiterate, I dont think that this will work.
We will need to add specific fields as I explained in https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/23847#discussion_r59301275.
But fine to get this in as is and fix later.

What's the difference between Ready and Offline? And why do they have have the opposite sense? For instance, this isn't this "Online"? 

If Offline is about reachability, it should be called Reachable.

I believe when a cluster is ready, then other conditions should be generally false or absent.

When Ready becomes false, there could be one or more conditions that indicate the reason for that.

Offline is about reachability (#19313 [Cluster](https://github.com/quinton-hoole/kubernetes/blob/2015-01-05-ube-design-docs/docs/design/federation-phase-1.md#cluster) which I can change it to Unreachable if you prefer.

There may be more conditions (reason field also maybe) in the future to indicate the status of an unready cluster (like NodeOutOfDisk for NodeCondition)
FWIW, we've talked about generalizing this field to LastUpdateTime, so it could be used for probes, heartbeats, and whatever other approaches to keeping the info up to date.
What does this field mean? Every running binary has a release version.
Would you mind giving some suggestions?
Yes I think we can just delete this field. No one is using it.

You can add `---` before this TODO so that it does not appear in user documentation.
Example: https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/pkg/apis/extensions/v1beta1/types.go#L291
